claim: Recombinant HA antigens produced using BEVS have been shown to induce significantly higher levels of broadly cross-reactive antibodies against highly conserved regions of HA compared with egg-derived vaccines.
explanation: Four-panel figure comparing immune responses in adults aged 18–44 (panels A and C) and 45–64 (panels B and D) to four seasonal influenza vaccines: two egg-based inactivated quadrivalent vaccines (Fluzone IIV4, Fluarix IIV4), a cell-based inactivated quadrivalent vaccine (ccIIV4), and a recombinant HA vaccine produced in insect cells (RIV4). Panels A and B show the geometric mean ratio of HAI titers against egg-grown versus cell-grown virus strains (A(H3N2), A(H1N1)pdm09, B/Victoria, B/Yamagata) with 95% CIs and statistical comparisons. Panels C and D show the proportion of subjects with ≥4-fold reduced titers to cell-grown vaccine virus pre- and post-vaccination for the same strains and vaccines, with p-values for changes in the proportion. does not support the claim: the figure presents strain-specific HAI titers against egg- versus cell-grown viruses and proportions of reduced titers, but it does not present any data on broadly cross-reactive antibodies targeting highly conserved HA regions induced by the recombinant HA vaccine. Note: Interpretation limited by absence of direct measurements of broad cross-reactivity or stalk-specific antibodies; figure focuses on strain-matched HAI responses rather than conserved epitope binding.
